text:
What did early Canadian pioneers eat?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Edna Mott
Address Creelman, Sask.
Birthplace Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? I helped my mother from 1902.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Creelman, Sask. (with parents)
Where had you been living before that? Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 8
How far was it to your nearest store? 40 miles - Weyburn or Lumsden
How often could a visit be made to the store? Always done by mail (transport)
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Sugar (brown, white), tea (black, green), brown sugar, syrup, cranberries, evaporated apples, spice extracts, raisins, currents, black strap, apples - 5 lbs., salt, soap (hard & soft), wash soda, eye, yeast, fresh lemons when possible, some candy, nuts, seeds, dates.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Ogilvie's! Think we got a year's supply delivered from Weyburn flour mills; our own grain.
In what quantities did you buy it? Twenty bags at a time.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.75
How much did you use graham flour? Bread, biscuits, muffins, quite a bit.
Whole wheat flour? As above.
Was flour milled locally? No... How far away? 40 miles (that year? 1903)
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 60¢
What other grain products did you use? Bran
Cornmeal? 5 lbs. of it
Whole wheat? None
Farina? Some for porridge
Other? Quills (wheat)
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
1. INTERVIEW QUESTIONS

   - What year did you start homesteading in eastern Oklahoma?
   - Where did you get your homestead land?
   - How far was it to your nearest store?
   - How often did you visit the store?
   - What crops did you usually grow?
   - How much did you use fertilizer?

2. FLORIDA AND OKLAHOMA PRODUCTS

   - What brand of flour did you use in the early years?
   - In what quantities did you buy?
   - What was the usual price per hundred pounds of flour?
   - How much did you use?
   - What flour did you mill locally?
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of flour?
   - What other grain products did you use?
   - Did you grind your own flour?
   - Did you grow your own corn?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs each brown white.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $5.98?

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Sue Anne.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? case of 6 ten pound pails.

At what price? It was old debt. I don't remember price.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Our own cows.

Butter? Own. Own. Eggs? Own. Own.

What was the price of butter? 25¢. Of eggs? 15¢ a day.

Did you pick eggs for inter? Yes. How? From raft.

Did you make butter? Yes. Cheese? No.

What kind of cheese? Cottage. We used a W. J. Stine.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Our own poultry, pork, beef, game.

How did you get fresh meat? Poultry, game.

How often did you get fresh meat? Once a week. Then winter.

How did you preserve meat? Ball canning. Summer.

Freeze it in winter.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not until 1921.

If so what year was it organized? About.

Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? Ducks, chicken, wild geese, wild turkey, all very plentiful.

For how long? Till about 1908. Too quickly settled after that.

What part did fish play in the family diet? There was plenty of fish. Mackerel, white, or salmon.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Kinds? Mackerel, white, jack.

Mother disliked salt fish so we never used it but bought a case or two of salmon each fall.
3. SUGAR AND STARCHES
In what quantity did you buy sugar? (e.g., 1 lb., 2 lbs., 5 lbs.)
What was the price for a ton pound? (e.g., $1.00)
What brand of flour did you use? (e.g., Gold Medal)
What size of tin or syrup did you usually buy? (e.g., 6 oz., 8 oz.)

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS
How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? (e.g., from cows, from store)
What was the price of butter? (e.g., $2.00 per lb.)
Did you make butter? (e.g., Yes, No)
What kind of cheese? (e.g., Cheddar, Mozzarella)

5. MEAT AND FISH
What was your meat supply in the early days? (e.g., pork, beef, game)
How did you get fresh meat? (e.g., from store, from butcher)
Did you use canned meat? (e.g., Yes, No)
Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? (e.g., Yes, No)
If so what year was it organized? (e.g., 1920)
Did you use piano? (e.g., Yes, No)
For how long? (e.g., 1900-1920)
Did you buy fish in the early days? (e.g., Yes, No)
What kind of fish? (e.g., salmon, cod, haddock)
Did you buy a case of two salmon each fall?

Handwritten notes:
- Handwritten text not visible due to image quality.

Handwritten answers:
- Handwritten answers not visible due to image quality.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Black ceylon at what price? $2.45?
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground at what price? $0.75
What other beverages were used? Cocoa, milk, lemonade when we had lemons—kept them sealed in glass jars quite a while.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $1.50
Could you get potatoes at the store? No
If not, where from? Farmer's barn about 8.00
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1903, Cabbage 1903, Carrots 1903, Onions 1903
Turnips 1903, Beets 1903

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 50 lbs. at least
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the boxes
What weight? 25 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?
What was the price of prunes? $0.75 very dear
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? .............
Beans? ........ Corn? ........ Beans? ........ Saskatoons? ........
Other foods? Yes ................................................................

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1903 (a little from Wolseley)
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1920
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1920
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes

To what extent? I put up a case of every fruit from my veg garden
Did you make your own vinegar? Only to a small extent
It keeps for months & could be freighted in
6. **Beverages**
   - What kind of tea did you buy? (Tea)
   - At what price? (42¢ per lb.)
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (Coffee or tea)
   - At what price? (5¢ per lb.)

7. **Vegetables and Fruits**
   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel?
   - Could you get potatoes at the store?
   - If not, where from?
   - What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
     - Potatoes (1942)
     - Cabbage (1942)
     - Turnips (1943)
     - Beets (1943)
   - In which quantities did you buy white navy beans?
   - How did you buy prunes? (In bulk or by the box)?
   - What weight? (2 lbs.)
   - How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?
   - What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, cherries, raisins, currants, etc.)
   - What other canned fruits did you use?

8. **Preservation**
   - In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying?
   - Other foods? (Yes)
   - What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? (1942)
   - What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? (1942)
   - What year did you first preserve meat by canning? (1942)
   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? (Yes)
   - To what extent? (Yes)
   - Did you make your own vinegar? (Yes)

9. **Tips for Survival**
   - Did you have a garden? (Yes)
   - Did you grow your own food? (Yes)
9. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                  | Your you first remember seeing it in the store | How was it sold? - In bulk, 10 lb. sack, can etc. | Ant. you usually bought at one time | Price |
|-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------|-------|
| Soda biscuits         | always                                        | 1 lb + larger boxes                               | 5 lbs, I don't know                |       |
| Macaroni              | 1917                                          | 1 lb boxes                                        | very little                        |       |
| Graham flour          | always                                        | 25, 50, 100 lb bgs.                               | 25 lbs                            |       |
| Brown sugar           |                                               | bulk, 20 lb, 100 lbs                              | 100 lbs                           |       |
| Molasses              |                                               | bulk, 1 lb cans                                   | 10 lbs                            |       |
| Table salt            |                                               | bulk, 50, 100 lb bgs.                             | 100                               |       |
| Common salt           |                                               |                                                  |                                    |       |
| Lily white syrup      | 1905                                          | 1, 5, 10 lb tins                                  | 10                                |       |
| Toilet soap           | always                                        | bulk boxes                                        | 5 lbs, I don't know                |       |
| Baking powder         | 1903                                          | 1 lb, 2 lb, 10 lbs                                | 5 lb                              |       |
| Baking soda           | always                                        | 1 lb                                             | we bought very few                 |       |
| Dried peas            | always                                        | bulk                                             | never bought                       |       |
| Dried corn            |                                               | bulk                                             | gallon, I don't know               |       |
| Vinegar               |                                               |                                                  |                                    |       |
| Raisins - seeded      |                                               | bulk, boxes                                      | 2-5 lbs                           |       |
| seedless              |                                               |                                                  |                                    |       |
| Rice                  | always                                        | bulk                                             | 10 lbs                            |       |
| Currants              |                                               |                                                  |                                    |       |
| Store jam - kinds?    | some pure - apple & peach, straw, plum, cherry peach apple butter honey |                                                  |                                    |       |
| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | always | large cheeses | 10 lb cheese |       |
| Vanilla               | always                                        | bottled                                          | 2 or 3 large bottles              |       |

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Bread Yeast, Cakes

Did you make yeast for your own use? No

Using hops? No

Salt rising? No

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda? Yes

Cream of tartar? Yes

Did you make your own baking powder? No

During early years in Ohio, always used soda & etc., later changing to baking powder.
10. Baking

What type of yeast did you use? **Commercial Yeast**

Did you make yeast for your own use? **No**

Using hops? **Yes**

Did you buy baking powder? **Yes**

Did you take your own baking powder? **No**

Buying early, using mother, then dry, and today dry.

Later changing to baking powder.
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                        | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------------|------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| Canned salmon               | always                                 | 15¢ for bests                | much better                                   |
| Canned sardines             |                                        | 3/25¢                       |                                               |
| Other canned fish that appeared early - Give names | herring                               |                              |                                               |
| Apples - fresh              | We got in a winter supply each fall    |                              |                                               |
|                             | dried                                  | We used a great many as sauce & pies |                                               |
| Lettuce                     | grew our own                           |                              |                                               |
| Tomatoes - fresh            | ripened our own after 1903 - our first garden |                              |                                               |
|                             | canned                                 | used about 5-6 cans a year   |                                               |
| Bananas                     | very seldom could get                  |                              |                                               |
| Lemons                      | got some when we could for lemon pie   |                              |                                               |
| Oranges                     | only at Xmas                           |                              |                                               |
| Cornflakes                  | 1910                                   | 10¢ a box                    | better, more weight                           |
| Other prepared breakfast    | 1910                                   |                              |                                               |
| cereals - give names        | Puffed wheat; rice                     |                              | coarser than now                              |
| Pearl tapioca               | always                                 | cheap                       | better                                        |
| Minute tapioca              | 1940                                   |                              |                                               |
| Sago                        | always                                 | cheap                       | not so well packed                            |
| Dates                       | always                                 | cheap                       |                                               |
| Walnuts                     | always                                 | cheap                       |                                               |
| Icing sugar                 | 1912                                   |                              |                                               |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) Our own excellent well

How far was this water from your home? A few yards

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Pail

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We got our laundry water from rain & slough. Now we have cisterns. Drinking water still from well.
5.

| Item          | Description                                                                 |
|---------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Apples        | Fresh we got our own supply each fall.                                      |
|               | Dried we used a good many as sauce & pies.                                  |
| Lettuce       | Grew our own.                                                                |
| Tomatoes      | Fresh - sufficient from own plot.                                            |
|               | Canned used about $1.00 can a year.                                          |
| Bananas       | Any seldom could get.                                                        |
| Lemons        | Only when we could find lemon pie.                                           |
| Oranges       | Only at Vero Beach.                                                          |
| Cornstalks    | 1910. Better, more weeded.                                                  |
| Pear Pickings | 1910. Better, more weeded.                                                   |
| Oranges       | Pear Pickings - Raffia wheat, rice...                                        |
|               | ...or worse than new.                                                        |
| Pear Tapioca  | Always cheap.                                                                |
| Himba Tapioca | 1940. Better.                                                                |
| Sago          | Always cheap.                                                               |
| Dates         | Always cheap.                                                               |
| Palmute       | Always cheap.                                                               |
| Icing Sugar   | 1912.                                                                       |

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout)

Water from well.

How far was this water from your house? A few yards.

Was it brought to the house? (Pail, barrel, tank)

We got our laundry water from rain little slough.

Now we have evoking, drinking water etc. from well.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? [handwritten]

If you made your own, did you use lye? [yes] wood ashes? [no]

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? [mostly Royal Crown Soap]

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? [wood, hard & soft coal]

Where did you get your fuel? [wood - Moore area, coal hauled from Walsby & Weyburn, till 1905 when R.R. came]

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

1912 We started using coal oil stoves (dangerous)
about then furnaces were installed
1940 fuel oils were used
1950 " " furnaces installed around here

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) [no]

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) [no]

By whom was your first cook stove made? [McClary's]

What year was it purchased? [1907] Price? [I don't know]

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) [iron, tin]

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) [also tin basins]

When did you first see enamel ware? [1950]

Aluminum? [1917?]
12. Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? 

If you made your own, did you mix it? 

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer usually sell? 

13. Fuel 

That fuel did you use in the earliest days? 

Where did you get your fuel? 

First started housekeeping, what did you have? 

14. We started using coal oil stoves (dangerous) 

1912 We started using coal oil stoves (dangerous) 

1940 Fuel ovens were installed 

1950 Furnaces installed around here 

15. Fireplaces 

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? 

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or back oven? 

What was your first cook stove made of? 

That year was it purchased? 

For preserving food? 

When did you first see aluminum? 

Altitude?
16. **SHOPPING AND CONTAINERS**

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Up till 1912 a great many foods were sold in bulk which was not sanitary. Flies were a terrible nuisance also mosquitoes. Nowadays they are practically a thing of the past—thanks to D.D.T.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

**Summer - breakfast**
- Grilled ham & eggs
- Toasted butter milk cream jam

**Dinner**
- Game
- Vegetables
- Pie (raisin or apple) milk tea

**Supper**
- Cold meat
- Creamed potatoes
- Pickles
- Honey or syrup

**Winter**
- Oatmeal
- Bacon eggs
- Toasted butter milk cream jam

Roast beef
- Vegetables (our own)
- Baked apples
- Milk tea

Cold beef
- Fried potatoes
- Pickles
- Apple butter
- Milk tea

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ...................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time. Our first Christmas dinner was 1902. I came home from school @ Ouappelle for the holidays 40 miles from Wolseley by team & sleigh—sitting on a box & hot feed oats, froze my nose and drove me—walking behind the sleigh most of the way. We had our own roast turkey, veg. soup, vegetables, cranberry sauce, fruit pudding, mince pie, all kinds of candy, apples, oranges nuts, etc. We had in grand presents for all. In addition to our own family mother invited two bachelor neighbors (in their twenties) to share dinner. We had built our piano & had a lovely time. Mother was really an excellent cook. I never knew anyone could beat her pie—lemon especially. Her recipe for it used milk not water yet I never excelled.

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. Never. We had excellent food always.

The only hazard we ever had was fuel shortage. Usually several neighbors went together for wood—two trips taking 3 days. Once they were delayed by blizzards & mother had bed-in the last armful of wood & planned to go to bed early if they did not arrive. However, a young student minister knocked on the door asking to stay the night. He was on horseback & he went to the barn & removed a manger & cut it up. The men got home by daybreak. The coal was not hauled as winter set in early that year (1904) so they hauled back coal from Wolseley as they hauled the grain there. We always had excellent food.
up all 1912 a great many foods were sold in bulk which was not available previously. Also were a terrible menace also mosquitoes nowadays they are practically a thing of past thanks to D.D.T.

17. Give a typical dinner menu (breakfast, dinner, and supper) for the year 1912. Include the numbers of each item purchased.

Summer - breakfast - grits - scrambled eggs - toast - butter - milk - cream

dinner - game - vegetables - peas - ham - bread - butter - milk

supper - cold meat - vegetables - noodles - gravy - butter - milk

Roast beef - vegetables (on own) baked apple - apple butter - milk

cold beef - fried potatoes - pickles - apple butter - milk

1903 my parents. We four girls 14 to 5, my mother 3, my half-brother Sutton who lived with us.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Kansas?

approximately 1902

19. How did you ever manage to almost starve to death living on one dollar a day? Give details.

The only hazard we ever had was fuel shortage. Usually our neighbors went together for wood - trip taking 3 days. Once they were delayed by sickness & mother had bill in the bank amount of wood & planned to go to bed early if they did not arrive. However a young student named Fernorch on the door asking to stay the night. He was on horseback & he went to the barn & removed a manager & old stove. The men returned by daylight. His case was well handled so winter aid in early fall. They hauled back coal from Weyburn as they hauled to the grain there. We always buy excellent food.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The food was better prepared then than now. Everything was given long slow cooking such as beans, tapioca, rice, roasts etc. Getting a meal was a rite that women took pride in - now its open a can or a package to hurry to catch the car or bus. There isn't nourishment in the modern food if it is far too dear for value received in nutrition. Cooking is an art not a sideline.

Modern meals include more raw salads such as carrot, cabbage also oranges & juices which are vitamin filled with food.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Not until I left the farm to live alone in this village in 1945 when my children all married & I cannot cook anything in quantity just for one.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

About 1906 when the railroad was here people began buying in quantity from J. Eaton Co Wfsg - sending as much as $100 for tea, coffee, jams, syrups etc.

Since the World War II, farm people do not bake bread, make butter. Some even use canned milk. But lots of them ship cream nearly all around here keep their summer meat in deep freeze lockers & they also can lots of meat, vegetables & meats too.
The food was better prepared than ever before. Everything was grown long ago working much on beans, tomatoes, rice, carrots etc. Getting a meal was a real treat. Women would go out - now it's open a can or a package of broth powder in - now it's open a can or a package of beef broth in - now it's open a can or a package of canned meat. Everything was cooked and eaten without any waste.

In the modern board of directors, there was no clear plan for value received in nutrition. Everything was cooked and eaten without any waste.

Modern meals include more raw foods and vegetables instead of canned goods. (Give an example of how to make a healthy meal.)

21. How did you feel about living alone in this small village in 1945 when my children all married?

& I cannot cook anything myself for our family until I left the farm & live alone in this small village in 1945 when my children all married.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries.

About 1906 when the railroad was built, free people began buying in quantity from Y. E. Co. Wey - sending as much as $500 for tea, coffee, jam, syrup etc.

Since the world war II, farm people do not take bread, make butter. Some even use canned milk. But lots of them ship cream nearly all around here keep their summer meal in deep freeze lockers & they also can lots of meat, vegetables & fruits etc.
